item.title: Covid: Sage scientists called for short lockdown weeks ago
item.description: Newly-released papers show Sage scientists described a "circuit breaker" as the best way to curb the virus.

item.title: Covid-19: Are we still listening to the science?
item.description: Sage and Prof Chris Whitty appear at odds with the political decisions made by government.

item.title: US election 2020: Trump back on campaign trail in Florida
item.description: President Trump is holding a campaign rally less than two weeks after testing positive for Covid-19.

item.title: Next year's exams in England delayed but still going ahead
item.description: A-levels and GCSEs to go ahead next year - but head teachers are angry at the lack of a back-up plan.

item.title: Covid: Threat of England hotspot travel ban to Wales
item.description: The first minister says he is giving Boris Johnson a final opportunity to impose curbs before he acts.

item.title: Facebook bans Holocaust denial content
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg says his "thinking has evolved" as the social network changes strategy.

item.title: Coronavirus: WHO head calls herd immunity approach 'immoral'
item.description: Dr Ghebreyesus said allowing coronavirus to spread unchecked would cause unnecessary suffering and death.

item.title: Museum of the Year: £200,000 prize split five ways amid 'financial peril'
item.description: Five museums and galleries share the coveted title of Museum of the Year title for 2020.

item.title: Harvester owner consulting on job cuts
item.description: Mitchells & Butlers, the pubs and restaurants group, has not disclosed how many jobs are at risk.

item.title: Agriculture bill: Bid to protect post-Brexit food standards rejected
item.description: MPs overturn a Lords amendment requiring trade deals to meet post-Brexit UK food standards.

item.title: Belarus protests: Police authorised to use lethal weapons
item.description: A top official says police can open fire on "violent radicals" protesting against the government.

item.title: Black man led by white police on horseback sues for $1m
item.description: Donald Neely was led down a Texas street "as though he was a slave", court documents say.

item.title: Kent Police officer sent 'flirtatious' messages to victim
item.description: Det Sgt Jonathan Pearce sent a topless photograph to the victim of attempted rape, a panel hears.

item.title: The Papers: 'Back to square one' as millions face new rules
item.description: The papers react to England's new three-tier Covid system, which sees new restrictions for Liverpool.

item.title: The dogs trained to sniff out Covid-19
item.description: Specially trained dogs in Lebanon are learning to detect coronavirus as part of a research project.

item.title: Nagorno-Karabakh: Civilians and churches under fire
item.description: Some of those displaced by fighting in the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh are sheltering in churches, but even those have been targeted.

item.title: Long Covid: Derbyshire woman says she uses swimming to help
item.description: Louise Buxton was a healthy, 47-year-old swimming teacher but now says she struggles with symptoms of Long Covid.

item.title: Mennel: 'I thought about giving up music'
item.description: Mennel Ibtissem became an internet sensation following her performance on The Voice France.

item.title: Covid care: 'It is very serious and it is very real'
item.description: Ward manager Nadine McStein explains the pressures on staff as coronavirus admissions rise again.

item.title: The battle over what US children learn about American history
item.description: As President Trump pushes "patriotic education", some teachers want US history curriculum reform.

item.title: Rugby League star won't let MND sap his spirit
item.description: BBC Breakfast has followed the Rugby League legend and his family since he was was diagnosed in 2019.

item.title: Pokemon: Rapper Logic spends £173,000 on rare Charizard card
item.description: Rapper Logic reportedly spent $226 thousand dollars on a rare Pokemon card.

item.title: Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett in her own words
item.description: What kind of justice might Amy Coney Barrett be? We take a look at her own words to find out.

item.title: Covid restrictions: Liverpool faces 'ominous winter ahead'
item.description: The Liverpool City Region is the first in England to be put on the "very high" Covid alert level.

item.title: Roe v Wade: What is US Supreme Court ruling on abortion?
item.description: A vacancy on the US Supreme Court has put the ruling which made abortion legal in the spotlight again.

item.title: Premier League revamp proposals explained
item.description: What are the key proposals of the Premier League revamp - and have your say.

item.title: Bars and restaurants 'reaching point of no return'
item.description: Hospitality venues across the UK say they will struggle under the new restrictions.

item.title: How to get promoted when working from home
item.description: If you are still not going back to the office, what's the best way to stand out from colleagues?

item.title: Strictly Come Dancing: 12 things we learned from this year's celebs
item.description: Clara Amfo, Caroline Quentin, JJ Chalmers, Nicola Adams and Maisie Smith are among the contestants.

item.title: EFL clubs could 'disappear in 5-6 weeks' without support
item.description: Some EFL clubs will "disappear within five to six weeks" unless they get financial support, says Nigel Travis, chairman of League Two Orient.

item.title: LA Lakers win NBA Finals: 'LeBron's legacy & a fitting farewell to Kobe Bryant'
item.description: LeBron vs Jordan and a fitting farewell to Kobe Bryant - BBC Sport's Nesta McGregor on LA Lakers' NBA Finals win.

item.title: 'That is a viral knockout' - UFC fighter Joaquin Buckley floors opponent with Mortal Kombat kick
item.description: UFC middleweight Joaquin Buckley delivers a spinning back kick that floors opponent Impa Kasanganay.

item.title: Man City's De Bruyne out of Belgium squad
item.description: Kevin de Bruyne withdraws from the Belgium squad to face Iceland on Wednesday and returns to Manchester City.

item.title: O'Sullivan fights back to defeat world number 127 Ochoiski
item.description: Ronnie O'Sullivan wins four successive frames to see off world number 127 Brian Ochoiski in the first round of the English Open.

item.title: Palace consider Benrahma bid as West Ham focus on King - Tuesday's football gossip
item.description: West Ham switch sole focus to Bournemouth forward, Man City to target Ajax left-back, plus more.

item.title: West Ham 'very much against' plans for Project Big Picture
item.description: West Ham would be against radical plans by Liverpool and Manchester United to reform the English football pyramid, according to a club insider.

item.title: Local lockdown rules: Check Covid restrictions in your area
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid rules: How will the three-tier lockdown system work?
item.description: How will the new restrictions in England work in practice?

item.title: Should I get a flu jab this winter?
item.description: Getting a flu jab could help protect you from influenza, but how can it help in the fight against coronavirus?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Coronavirus cases are increasing, so what are the rules on social distancing?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Job Support Scheme: What is changing after furlough?
item.description: The government has expanded its Job Support Scheme for people who can't work due to local restrictions.

item.title: Local lockdown UK: Do city-wide curbs work? It's not clear
item.description: One in four people in the UK is currently subject to local interventions to prevent the spread of Covid.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is self-isolation and who has to do it?
item.description: If you are told to self-isolate, how long must you do it for, and what are the rules?

item.title: Covid: How should I talk to neighbours who break the rules?
item.description: With new restrictions on social gatherings how can you raise concerns without causing arguments?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: Travellers arriving from almost all other countries must self-isolate on entry to the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is anxiety and how can I get help?
item.description: Changes in all our lives have increased anxiety levels but there is support and advice available.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does the tier system mean for UK holidays?
item.description: Where can I go and what can I do on a holiday in the UK?

item.title: Europe lockdown: New coronavirus rules country-by-country
item.description: What are European countries doing to control new coronavirus outbreaks?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who are the Covid marshals and do they have any powers?
item.description: Covid marshals have been suggested as a way of ensuring people follow social distancing rules.
